This is my most played and my favourite game. I've played since the beta and realized I haven't done a review yet so here it finally is. 

This game is a FPS PVE hoard shooter/hack and slash game. The game doesn't get really good until you've maxed out your character and started running the harder missions which is a pretty big time investment. What makes this game fun to me is the fast paced aggressive team based gameplay that has a very high skill cap. To be clear, this is not a shooting game, your "primary weapon" is your meelee weapon. That being said, you can create a build to be a shooter primarily but if you are not skilled at meelee combat you'll weigh your team down. 

Some of the best things about this game are the sound design, atmosphere, and build crafting. The music is phenomenal with a techno synth organ music that is layered with opera singing and punchy baselines that pairs really well with some great voiceacting, sound fx, and sounds cues. The sound plays a huge part in the gameplay as you can hear the sounds very clearly of your enemies and being able to do a 180 and punch an enemy in the mouth before they can finish an attack because you hear the attack sound cue is incredibly satisfying. The maps and atmosphere capture the parts of warhammer 40k that make it so interesting. Looking over the side of the map to see the "skybox"/background textures can be very captivating. The class builds you can make keep the game feeling interesting to me as you come to learn what nodes are worth taking and which nodes work better depending on what you're going for with your class. Each class feels unique but similar in many ways and each class can be a lot of fun to play. Getting a well rounded team in an auric lobby and crushing the mission is a feeling that I have never gotten from any other game I've played.

Some of the biggest issues with this game is unfortunately tied to some of the best parts about this game. The most fun content is the harder content and the skill required to play at that level is not always there with people. The reason I find the harder missions more fun is because they up the spawns of all the enemies so there will be times in the mission where you are literally tearing through the hoards of enemies but if you have a teammate who is bad and falls behind, you are not going to have as good of a time. Bad players is not one of the issues I have with this game but rather the community that has arisen around the fact that there is so much varying degrees of skill in this game. Let's face it, we all know warhammer 40k fans can "just be like that" . in addition to the fun content being with the harder missions, it takes a significant time commitment to get to that level and often times, the community may not be as welcoming or helpful as it should be which may deter players from getting the same enjoyment from this game as I do. 

All that being said, seeing a massive hoard of enemies and being able to charge into them confidently head first and pushing the hoard back because you have a competent team that is right beside you and ready to back you up is so satisfying. Similarily, seeing your teammate being pushed back by a hoard and popping your ability and feeling the momentum shift from being pushed back by the hoard to pushing the hoard back and creating the space for your team to proceed is the best part of this game. Hitting a charge ability to back up a teammate, popping a damage ult and melting a boss for your team, getting overwhelmed and hitting your support ultimate or dropping a stun ability at just the right time, switching to your range weapon and taking the head off a pox houd that just jumped your teammate. 

This game is a no brainer for me to recommend on sale but if you're on the fence about this at regular price I would recommend at least pushing to level 30 on a couple of classes and playing at least a heresy maelstrom match or three before you decide if you really like the game or not. If you don't have the time to committ to that and don't love PVE hoard shooters than I would not recommend this to you at regular price. I've put in 586 hrs in this game at the time of this review and I'm still getting better at it the more I play and I haven't even tried the true end game yet. You'll probably be able to get at least 10-20 hours out of this game if you're on the fence about it and are ok with failing a bit as you learn it

So far, Darktide is one of the best Warhammer 40k games and one of the best horde shooters on the market. The game has come a long way since its release. Many new missions have been added, character progression trees have been expanded, and weapon progression has been improved. In my opinion, optimization has also improved. New updates are released regularly, so the game is constantly being developed.

   The game offers four very different character classes and one paid class (a second paid class, Hive Scum, will be added on December 2). Character progression is well balanced, with the player receiving one point for the development tree with each level up. This means that the player does not have to grind empty levels to max out a given character. In addition, each class has extensive development trees containing 3 archetypes of a given class that can be freely mixed and matched. The arsenal has also been greatly expanded since the release, and its progression has been improved, with crafting being changed to be fully deterministic instead of random, resulting in easier build creation.

   As for the combat system, it is a slightly modified version of the one from Vermintide 2. The combat system is well suited for fighting numerous enemies thanks to the clave mechanic.  However, this system has a drawback because the only things that limit attacks are attack speed and animation length, so combat can feel like a clicker (though it should be noted that spamming light attacks is rarely profitable/optimal). Each weapon has a different moveset, which means that some weapons are better suited for clearing large waves of smaller enemies, while others are better at dealing with heavy opponents. When it comes to ranged combat, the gunplay is also well done, with ranged weapons having appropriately made animations and good sound effects.  Enemies fighting from a distance can hide behind cover when shot at and can also provide covering fire. In addition, the game is diverse in terms of enemy types. There are 27 different types of enemies in the game (my method of counting enemy types takes into account the type of combat and the type of armor).

   In terms of content, Darktide currently offers 22 missions, a more difficult Havoc game mode, and a similar roguelike mode called Mortis Trials, but to be honest, this particular mode is not very extensive.

   Of course, it's not a flawless game. The game is not without bugs (although I must admit that I encounter bugs less often than not). The game likes to crash, usually during updates or after installing mods. My theory is that the culprit may be the Autodesk Stingray game engine. The same crash problem occurs in both Fatshark and Helldivers 2 games, and the engine itself is no longer being developed. The game itself is also being developed rather slowly, sometimes you really have to wait a long time for new content. Despite being “buy to play,” the game does feature cosmetic microtransactions. The price and content of the paid classes may also be debatable; I think $12 for the basic DLC version is too high (although I can say that the Adeptus Arbites DLC provided me with content for less than 100 hours to completely level up that DLC). 

   Darktide has its problems, but today it is one of the best horde shooters and one of the most interesting titles in the Warhammer 40k universe. Fatshark has clearly refined the game after its poor launch, and I can honestly recommend it in its current state. If I had to rate this game on a scale of 1-10, I think 8/10 would be fair, although I would even be inclined to give it 8.5/10. A rating of 9/10 would definitely be too stretched.

I'll gladly recommend you Space Marine 2 as an alternative, which has identical or better overall quality in every core aspect (art, optimization, fluid gameplay) but it also offers a coherent story in form of a proper singleplayer campaign, and the cooperative repeatable mission grind ties into the singleplayer campaign (such as Titus commands another squad on radio in SP, but you play as that squad in repeatable coop missions) and the unlockables are fixed premade straight up upgrades to weapons, without overcomplicated "+0.3% damage if the sun is at it's apex while the Emperor is doing a rap battle in the Immaterium and you spin 360 degrees before you click shoot" skill trees.
